criticalSuccess: You approach with perfect speed, plant your feet at exactly the right spot, and explode upward with tremendous power. Your legs drive like pistons, launching you high into the air. You soar upward, easily clearing the obstacle with height to spare, before landing in perfect balance on the other side. It's a textbook vertical leap!

With explosive athleticism, you convert your momentum into vertical lift. Your powerful legs propel you skyward, and for a moment you seem to hang in the air. You clear the height with impressive room to spare, demonstrating remarkable jumping ability!

Your technique is flawless - the approach, the plant, the drive upward all combine perfectly. You vault high into the air with the grace and power of a professional athlete, making the difficult jump look effortless!
success: You time your jump well, driving upward with solid force. Your leap carries you to the required height, though just barely. You clear the obstacle successfully.
You manage to generate enough upward power to make the jump. It's not spectacular, but it works - you reach the needed height.
Your vertical leap gets you over the obstacle. Your technique is functional and your strength sufficient for the task.
failure: You give it your all, legs driving as hard as they can, but you simply don't get high enough. Your jump falls short of the required height, and you can't clear the obstacle.
Despite your best effort, your vertical leap is insufficient. You don't have the power or technique to reach that high. You come up short.
You jump as high as you can, but it's not enough. The obstacle remains just out of reach, your upward momentum petering out before you clear it.
criticalFailure: Your approach is too fast or your plant is off - either way, your takeoff goes terribly wrong. Instead of launching upward, you stumble awkwardly, barely getting airborne before landing in an ungainly heap. It's more of a trip than a jump!
As you drive into your jump, your lead foot slips. Your carefully timed leap becomes a flail, and you barely leave the ground before stumbling back down, off-balance and embarrassed!
You miscalculate everything - speed, angle, timing. Your attempted jump is a disaster. You barely get six inches off the ground before your legs give way and you nearly fall flat!

criticalSuccess: Like a coiled spring suddenly released, you explode upward with breathtaking power. Your legs drive into the ground with such force you can feel the impact reverb ate up your spine. Then you're airborne, rising swiftly, the obstacle shrinking beneath you. At the apex of your jump, you seem to hang suspended for a heartbeat, defying gravity. Then descent begins, controlled and graceful. You clear the obstacle with meters to spare, landing with cat-like balance. The jump is magnificent - a perfect demonstration of explosive athletic power!

Your approach is poetry in motion - each stride building momentum, muscles coiling like springs ready to unleash. At the perfect moment, you plant and drive. The force of your takeoff is explosive. You rocket skyward, body perfectly positioned for maximum vertical lift. Time seems to slow as you soar upward, easily clearing heights that would stop others. Your landing is equally perfect - balanced, controlled, effortless. This is how high jumping is meant to be done!
success: You execute a competent vertical leap. Good approach, solid plant, adequate drive upward. You reach the required height with no wasted motion, clearing the obstacle efficiently if not spectacularly.
Your jump works. You generate enough upward power to reach the necessary height, clear the obstacle, and land safely. Textbook functional athletics.
failure: You give it everything you have. Your approach is good, your form decent, your effort maximum. But sometimes physics and biology impose hard limits. You jump as high as your body can manage, and it's simply not enough. You come up short despite your best effort.

Gravity defeats you this time. You launch upward with committed effort, but you can feel midway through the jump that you won't make it. Your upward momentum bleeds away too quickly, and you fall short of the height needed.
criticalFailure: Everything goes catastrophically wrong from the very start. Your approach speed is off, throwing your timing. When you plant for the jump, your foot finds an unexpected divot or slick patch. The carefully choreographed sequence of movements that should result in a powerful vertical leap instead becomes a stumbling, flailing disaster. You barely leave the ground, legs tangling, balance lost. You come down awkwardly, having to scramble to avoid a complete fall. It's not just a failed jump - it's a comprehensive athletic failure!

In the critical moment when muscle, timing, and technique must align perfectly, they instead conspire against you. Your plant foot slips at the worst possible instant. Your drive leg buckles instead of driving. Your arms swing wrong. The result isn't a jump but a collapse. You hardly get airborne before gravity reasserts itself with cruel efficiency. You land badly, off-balance, having to catch yourself to avoid eating dirt. Any spectators would wince at the spectacular failure!

criticalSuccess: This is explosive power in its purest form. No run-up, no momentum, just raw athletic ability. You stand before the obstacle, coil your legs like compressed springs, and then unleash. The drive is phenomenal - every muscle in your legs firing in perfect synchronization. You rocket straight upward from standing position, defying the normal physics of jumping. Height comes not from speed but from pure power. You soar past the obstacle with room to spare, demonstrating that when you have this much explosive strength, momentum is optional!

Like a basketball player pulling off a standing vertical leap, you demonstrate freakish athletic ability. From a complete standstill, you compress into a crouch, then explode upward with devastating force. Your legs drive like pistons, generating tremendous vertical thrust despite having zero forward momentum. You launch skyward, clearing heights that most people couldn't reach with a running start. It's a showcase of pure explosive power!

criticalFailure: You commit to the standing jump with full confidence. Legs coil, muscles tense, ready to explode upward. Then everything breaks down. You barely get airborne before control is lost, and you land awkwardly, having to catch yourself to avoid injury!

You compress into your approach, every muscle coiling like a spring under tremendous tension. Then you release. The explosion is tremendous.
